sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving gases
message_1: What is the standard enthalpy change for the reaction 2SO2(g) + O2(g) → 2SO3(g) at 25°C and 1 atm pressure, given the following enthalpy of formation values: ΔfH°[SO2(g)] = -296.8 kJ/mol, ΔfH°[O2(g)] = 0 kJ/mol, and ΔfH°[SO3(g)] = -395.72 kJ/mol?
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the formula:

ΔH°(reaction) = Σ ΔfH°(products) - Σ ΔfH°(reactants)

For the given reaction, 2SO2(g) + O2(g) → 2SO3(g), we have:

ΔH°(reaction) = [2 × ΔfH°(SO3)] - [2 × ΔfH°(SO2) + ΔfH°(O2)]

Given the enthalpy of formation values:

ΔfH°[SO2(g)] = -296.8 kJ/mol
ΔfH°[O2(g)] = 0 kJ/mol
ΔfH°[SO3(g)] = -395.72 kJ/mol

Substitute these values into the equation:

ΔH°(reaction) = [2 × (-395.72)] - [2 × (-296.8) + 0]
ΔH°(reaction) = (-791.44) - (-593.6)
ΔH°(reaction) = -197.84 kJ/mol

So, the standard enthalpy change for the reaction 2SO2(g) + O2(g) → 2SO3(g) at 25°C and 1 atm pressure is -197.84 kJ/mol.
